question.title: AssertionError in Gson EnumTypeAdapter when using Proguard Obfuscation

node.contents: My project implements a TypeAdapter in Gson during serialization/deserialization for preserving object's polymorphism state. Anyhow, the project works fine during development tests, but when it is released with proguard obfuscation and tested, it just crashes.

astNode.text: My project implements a TypeAdapter in Gson during serialization/deserialization for preserving object's polymorphism state. Anyhow, the project works fine during development tests, but when it is released with proguard obfuscation and tested, it just crashes.

elements.contents:
##---------------Begin: proguard configuration for Gson  ----------
# Gson uses generic type information stored in a class file when working with fields. Proguard
# removes such information by default, so configure it to keep all of it.
-keepattributes Signature

# For using GSON @Expose annotation
-keepattributes *Annotation*

# Gson specific classes
-keep class sun.misc.Unsafe { *; }
#-keep class com.google.gson.stream.** { *; }

# Application classes that will be serialized/deserialized over Gson
-keep class com.google.gson.examples.android.model.** { *; }

#This is extra - added by me to exclude gson obfuscation
-keep class com.google.gson.** { *; }

##---------------End: proguard configuration for Gson  ----------

##---------------Begin: proguard configuration for Gson  ----------
# Gson uses generic type information stored in a class file when working with fields. Proguard
# removes such information by default, so configure it to keep all of it.
-keepattributes Signature

# For using GSON @Expose annotation
-keepattributes *Annotation*

# Gson specific classes
-keep class sun.misc.Unsafe { *; }
#-keep class com.google.gson.stream.** { *; }

# Application classes that will be serialized/deserialized over Gson
-keep class com.google.gson.examples.android.model.** { *; }

#This is extra - added by me to exclude gson obfuscation
-keep class com.google.gson.** { *; }

##---------------End: proguard configuration for Gson  ----------

node.contents: I did a lot of search on this error specific to Gson, but couldn't find any helpful answer. However I found another question with the similar issue.

astNode.text: I did a lot of search on this error specific to Gson, but couldn't find any helpful answer. However I found another question with the similar issue.

node.contents: Any help from developer's community would be appreciated.

astNode.text: Any help from developer's community would be appreciated.

node.contents: After running into the same problem, I went through and examined the resulting APK decompiled. I believe the problem is related to some enum type losing its members during obfuscation.

astNode.text: After running into the same problem, I went through and examined the resulting APK decompiled. I believe the problem is related to some enum type losing its members during obfuscation.

node.contents: Also - make sure ALL of the classes being used in GSON are being retained:

astNode.text: Also - make sure ALL of the classes being used in GSON are being retained:

</fields>

node.contents:
As-is: 
<fields>
 , 
 <methods>
  , 
  <init>
   , **, *, and ? are wildcards that ProGuard recognizes.
  </init>
 </methods>
</fields>

As-is:

  </init>
 </methods>
</fields>

node.contents: GSON throws this AssertionError when it fails to deserialize enumeration constants from JSON data, performing introspection on the fields of the enum class. Unfortunately, it swallows the details of the underlying NoSuchFieldException.

astNode.text: GSON throws this AssertionError when it fails to deserialize enumeration constants from JSON data, performing introspection on the fields of the enum class. Unfortunately, it swallows the details of the underlying NoSuchFieldException.

node.contents: You should make sure that you preserve the names of the enum fields (and of fields in general) that are serialized. By default, ProGuard may rename or even remove them. For instance, with some wildcards:

astNode.text: You should make sure that you preserve the names of the enum fields (and of fields in general) that are serialized. By default, ProGuard may rename or even remove them. For instance, with some wildcards:

node.contents: It is already suggested that you need to configure Proguard in a way that it keeps every enum related to serialized objects intact. I don't really like the fact that I have to explicitly list all my enums, this solution is hard to maintain. A slightly better solution I came up with is the following.

astNode.text: It is already suggested that you need to configure Proguard in a way that it keeps every enum related to serialized objects intact. I don't really like the fact that I have to explicitly list all my enums, this solution is hard to maintain. A slightly better solution I came up with is the following.

node.contents: Use an empty interface to indicate that a class or enum takes part in Gson serialization:

astNode.text: Use an empty interface to indicate that a class or enum takes part in Gson serialization:

node.contents: Use a Proguard config that keeps both the interface and all classes/enums that implement it:

astNode.text: Use a Proguard config that keeps both the interface and all classes/enums that implement it:

fragments.text:
interface, it would be thrown away by proguard since it is empty
-keep

# member fields of serialized classes, including enums that implement this interface
-keepclassmembers class * implements

node.contents: That's it, as long as your classes and enums use the interface, you should be OK. You could also enforce the presence of this interface in your serialization/deserialization methods, so you don't forget it when adding a new class later:

astNode.text: That's it, as long as your classes and enums use the interface, you should be OK. You could also enforce the presence of this interface in your serialization/deserialization methods, so you don't forget it when adding a new class later:

node.contents: Also in your configuration the line with 'com.google.gson.examples.android.model.** { *; }' refers to some Google related example code, so I don't think it is necessary.

astNode.text: Also in your configuration the line with 'com.google.gson.examples.android.model.** { *; }' refers to some Google related example code, so I don't think it is necessary.

node.contents: In my case, proguard was configured to -keep individual classes touched by Gson, but the error went away when I configured proguard to retain the package where those individual classes resided:

astNode.text: In my case, proguard was configured to -keep individual classes touched by Gson, but the error went away when I configured proguard to retain the package where those individual classes resided:
